politician that risks alienating financial supporters to woo public 
supporters....to get elected), and/or (b) individual righteousness (some 
politicians *actually* want what's best).

We keep trying, keep the public informed, keep "righting the boat", and

comments.text:
+Shoor Muse It's a good question, but it actually does to me.

You know, if a politician is bribed they have to vote in possibly a 
damaging way. But they have to win an election still. If people still vote 
for that person then obviously they are still saying they support him, You 
can say that's just because of marketing but then you're basically saying 
the majority of people don't have their own independent thought

Everyone has their own opinion, but i'd strongly advise people to listen to 
their policy and look at track records and how much they really trust a 
candidate before voting but i don't believe that i can force them to do 
that. They can vote for the person if they have the shiniest tie or the 
best TV ad if they want to. That is the point of democracy.

Democracy may not be the best system, but if you support democracy then i 
believe you have to let everyone vote the way they want to, and if you 
believe in capitalism then it would incomprehensible to support 
criminalizing donations. Although you could try and criminalize government 
extending it's powers which is what the right wing with good intentions are 
trying to do, whilst you liberals with good intentions are doing the whole 
wolf pac thing.

You just can't take the moral high ground because i think it's pretty 
obvious both sides are trying to do what they think is moral.

top_comment.text:
hate to rain on your parade, but...
it's like having a shit cake with a shit filling and a shit topping, and 
you're so glad you got rid of the shit topping :)
politics is exactly like that : corruption on top of corruption masked by 
"legal" bribing.
so, gratz on your small victory. And bon appetite :D﻿
top_comment.author: Ferodaktyl

comments.text:
"hate to rain on your parade, but"
Translation: "How dare you have a parade!  I'll piss on it and tell you 
it's raining!"
comments.author: johnmburt1960

comments.text:
Oh good...glad we can't change anything.  So then, we're still cave-people, 
right?  We don't have fire, or the wheel, or writing, or agriculture, or 
any form of organized social structure at all, or anything that follows 
from any of it.

Grow up.  Things change.  Either we will collapse, and the intelligentsia 
will rebuild apart from the rest...or we'll manage to limp along until we 
repair enough damage to stand and fix the rest.

Either way, it won't stay as it is.
comments.author: OriginalTharios

comments.text:
So your criticism is that this is only solving one many problems? I don't 
see why that's a bad thing. It's not like solving this problem somehow 
prevents you from solving the others. Now that the shit topping is gone 
we've got one less problem, and we can work on the others, and eventually 
get a good cake.
comments.author: Oicurmtoyoy

comments.text:
Yes, we should all be apathetic cynics like you, this would clearly get 
things done faster...
comments.author: Parralyzed

comments.text:
At least Cenk and many others are trying to solve the problem. What exactly 
are you doing to make things better?
comments.author: Cloudhopper4

top_comment.text: Vermont is the only habitable state for a Canadian.﻿
top_comment.author: AJ Ace A-N

comments.text:
+Jesse Wright Never been. I'll stick with Canada. Easier to find the nice 
folks :).
comments.author: PirateDion

comments.text: +Jesse Wright And if your Canada wasn't so cold I'd move there!
comments.author: John Lynn

comments.text: +sabotore Sounds about right to me
comments.author: Jesse Wright

comments.text:
Canadians love Washington state though, at least the ones in British 
Columbia. Washington is pretty similar politically to British Columbia, In 
fact Canada actually had a dispute over the land there. But I believe they 
settled that with the Oregon Treaty in the 1840's.
comments.author: sabotore

comments.text:
+PirateDion Very true. Unless you are in Wisconsin. They are the most 
Canadian Americans I have ever met!
comments.author: Jesse Wright

comments.text:
+AJ Ace A-N Habitable weather wise? Or because of the people there? Many 
places in America are "habitable" weather wise... but the people make it a 
bit difficult to find a replacement from what you find in Canada.
comments.author: PirateDion

comments.text:
+John Lynn In fact, many go so far south to get away from the cold. If 
America wasn't too fucked up, I'd move too.

I'll just head to somewhere in Europe. Europe loves Canucks.
comments.author: Jesse Wright

comments.text:

 Dutchman.  I guarantee it isn't too hot.
comments.author: John Lynn

comments.text: New York isn't a bad choice either.

top_comment.text: Okay Cenk. Now, how are politicians going to be funded?﻿
top_comment.author: chris mills

comments.text:
I'll take a stab at this as this is what we have in Canada. Funding limits. 
A person is only allowed to give "X" amount of dollars and companies are 
not considered people. So, it doesn't matter how rich you are, you're 
limited to what you can donate. Forces politician's to actually have to 
stay connected to their constituents and actually listen to them. They need 
to get a bunch of little cheques rather than 2 or 3 big cheques.
comments.author: Adam Warlock

comments.text:
+Crocmaster McGeezax
That is the way it should be.  Every person running gets X per constituent 
in the district he is running in.  A fine for not voting is a graet 
concept.  Australia fines their citizens for not voting
comments.author: Theodore Zipes

comments.text:
Everybody gets an equivalent amount of taxpayer funds. I believe in no 
political ads and a fine for not voting as well.
comments.author: Crocmaster McGeezax

comments.text: by their bloated salary.
comments.author: GeeKeD-OuT

comments.text: publicly, they do that in other developed countries
comments.author: Alex Sitaras

top_comment.text:
this amendment isnt going to make it. its going to get the popular vote but 
wont make it through. why? because of the corrupt congress being paid at 
this moment to do their best to shut it down. money will stay in politics. 
money will forever rule america. and money will forever rule the world.﻿

comments.text:
course they can. you dont think they can rig elections? happens every year.

comments.author: NICKownsHALO27

comments.text:
Congress can't stop a constitutional convention by the states to add the 
28th amendment...that's the whole point of this. The founding fathers were 
very wise to foresee a need to bypass federal the government. You should 
check out what wolfpac is about before giving up.
comments.author: Richard Locksley
